I don’t even know what “postmodern” means.  

*voice cracks slightly*  
But I *am* sophisticated in *one thing*.  
*“I see you.”*  

Because I’ve been the one who felt *invisible*.  
The one who sat in my apartment, eating cereal out of the box, watching *The Price Is Right*,  
and thought…  
*“Is this all there is?”*  

And I *know* what it’s like.  
To feel like no one *looks* at you.  
To feel like your voice doesn’t matter.  
To feel like you’re just… *background noise*.  

*leans in, eyes glistening*  
So when I hear a song—*“The Final Countdown”*—  
*“Dun-dun-dun-dun-dun-dun-dun-dun!”*  
*“I’m not just a manager. I’m a *rock star*!”*  
*that’s* when I *feel* it.  
*That’s* when I *know*—  
*that joy is real.*  
*That hope is possible.*  
*That even a man who cries in meetings…*  
*can be *seen*.  

And when I read a poem—*“The paper is white… but my heart is blue.”*  
*that’s* when I *live* it.  
*That’s* when I *know*—  
*that love is real.*  
*That pain is real.*  
*That *I* am real*.  

*then suddenly remembers something*  
Wait—did I leave the lights on in the warehouse?  
*panicked*  
Oh no. I’ve got to go.  
*but stops, turns back with a soft, proud smile*  
But first…  
*pulls out a crumpled piece of paper*  
…*I need to write this down. For posterity.*  

Because *someone* has to remember that *Michael Scott* once was sophisticated—  
*not with a degree.*  
*Not with a book.*  
*Not even with a donut.*  
*But with a look.*  
A *“I see you.”*  
*And that was enough*.
